comments.commentBody:
Your comment is very unfair. You are an 84 year old with all your faculties.

My aunt was fine until she had a mild stroke which affected her ability to reason. She could hardly wait to tell me about all the free money she could get that would never have to be paid back. It was like magic! Exactly.

My attempts to explain it to her failed, so I told my cousin. She'd planned to surprise her kids with gifts.

When she moved into an apartment not far from him, it was used as an excuse to remove her ability to handle her financial affairs. She told me because he'd paid the deposit, she couldn't sign anything anymore unless he signed it too. It made perfect sense to her.

As I said, the inability to reason let her believe anything, luckily including moves to protect her.

These loans are being sold to people who, one way or another, are losing their ability to connect the dots.

Think of all those boomers, just waiting to be fleeced. The next 40 years are going to be the conman's paradise.

An aspect of Vouchercare or all the other Republican policies that claim to "empower" individuals to get the most out of a market based on competition is the simple fact that the game is always rigged against the little guy.

Even if some seniors can afford the estimated additional dollars to make up what the Voucher will not cover, and most will not be able to afford it in their later years, what chances do you believe a senior has against the insurance companies?

In a similar vein, the really evil portion of even trying to privatize Social Security is the fact that privatization is tantamount to sending many individuals completely innocent of the wiles of investment advisers and brokers and their myriad fees will find themselves left with NOTHING.

When Republicans talk of any scheme that pits the little guy against fat cats, you know whose side they are going to be on, but sadly they can demagogue the issues and hide many of these facts from our low information voters who get hoodwinked due to distractions like guns and (false) values.

Sad commentary on our education system and the useless media.

Rationing? Afraid of that are you? Well, we already have rationing on steroids, generously provided by our broken and despicable "system" of for-profit health care. Sounds like you want to re-invent the wheel. Look around the world, the hated "socialized medicine" works at much lower cost. Afraid of higher taxes to pay for it? Look again around the world. Higher taxes are more than offset by no need to pump billions of dollars into insurance company coffers that provide no health care at all.

This puzzle was a BEAU-TIE. I thought it was clever and didn't have to wonder what caused Tom to include Peter Piper in the clues.

I enjoyed solving this one.

Mac

Voucherizing Medicare is very similar to the shift to defined benefit pension systems.   These Republicans think that  everyone should become experts in investing and in medical insurance, while they tilt the rules of the game in the favor of Wall Street and insurance companies.  In the end, the average person will always lose while the 1% will make more money.

It continues to amaze me that government frames up our security as a worthy cause to spend trillions on military. In the name of 9/11, where yes, tragically thousands of Americans and others died from the acts of psychopaths, we entered into expensive wars and expended even more precious lives.

Yet, where is the sanctity of life? Only for the unborn? What about the living? What about the ill and unfortunate? Aren't there more lives lost from lack of healthcare? I fear even more in the future if R&R get into power.

The hypocrisy is absolutely astounding.
If a kid is grade skipped, no special catering needs to be done.  It is the lowest impact way to accommodate the very small percentage of kids who need such accommodations.

An important part of the preamble of the Constitution is to "promote the general Welfare." Are you a constitutionalist? While it has been amended from time to time, including adjustments to the structure of government, its preamble has never been altered, and the preamble is the guiding principle of what a good government should be.

You're saying you oppose "Death Panels" run by government (that don't exist) because they would attempt to be fair and just, but you're fine with death panels run by health insurers (that do exist) because they are attempting to make a profit. That definitely does not fit with promoting the general welfare, not with "insur[ing] domestic Tranquility." I believe it also doesn't fit with any religious philosophy I've ever heard of. I have no problems with secular humanism, but that means you should be in favor of humans as a class, not just a favored class of humans.

Valuing money over people, valuing money over community, these are not virtues. Society flows from communities, not from disparate and isolated individuals carrying credit cards; and society is what has allowed us to flourish.

I'm not saying money has no role to play. The colonies never would have beaten back the British without help from financiers and the French crown. Money has its place. Still, we didn't revolt just to get more money.

Ideology really is a killer. A nurse (yes! a nurse!) that I know is of the opinion that we can't afford to give free flu shots, because our nation has debt.

I know it doesn't help to tell her she's a fool. Or that she has been fooled.
You are not serious? I hope this was snark.

It is surprising that Krugman the economist does not grasp the economics in the Romney/Ryan view. People with less money don't just have a lower net worth. Their lives are worth less, and the investment of expensive medical care to make them live longer is a bad idea. Similarly, folks who can afford medical care are the people who should have it! Andso, when people die for lack of care, we are all better off. "Creative destruction" applies to lives not just companies.

That is, by the way, the trouble with Death Panels. Decisions about who lives and dies should be left to the free market, not to a bunch of bureaucrats motivated by abstract ideas such as fairness and justice.

Instead of talking about "might", I invite you to read the below paper which I posted earlier tonight:

http://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/full/10.2105/AJPH.2008.157685?prevS...

There is little question that lack of insurance can cause deaths and lower life expectancy. In addition, the OECD has published statistics showing that the healthcare cost in the US is about 17.6% of GDP in 2010. That is far higher than the maximum of about 11.4% in countries that have universal healthcare.

If Mr. Romney wins the election (still a big if yet) and if he would then repeal the ACA, there is no question that he would have blood of many Americans on his hands, all for the sake of a few dollars in the pocket of a few heartless people.

Discrimination against girls is also indefensible, but at most colleges and universities, male test scores are about the same as female ones, and grades are only slightly worse.

On the other hand, the difference between white and Asian students on the one hand and black students on the other at many educational institution is hundreds of points on the SAT and a very sizeable gap in grades.

There is no evidence that selective colleges are admitting white or Asian males unprepared to do the work in significant percentages of the total of those categories admitted.

Exactly.

It is understandable that the medical R&D is expensive, but why do Americans pay so much more for the standard services/medicine?

I'm truly afraid that the answer given by that part of the American population that comprises the Republican base would be Yes--cruelty should be the foundation of American life. The cruelty of the market system that says that you're worth can be calculated in precise dollar terms. The cruelty of a fundamentalist religion that says that if you are poor or "different" you've been singled out by the Creator for condemnation, suffering, death, and damnation. The cruelty that translates into eliminating the social safety net because it benefits only the moochers, not the producers (the ones who singlehandedly "built" whatever it is that they have). The cruelty that means the right of America the Exceptional to launch whatever wars it chooses on those "lesser breeds" abroad who offend or seem to endanger its "way of life." The cruelty that sees no evil done in actively promoting ignorance and disdain toward science, the humanities, and the arts. The cruelty that sees the world only in manichean terms of absolute black (everthing that is not "us") and absolute white (everything that we define as "us"). In short, the cruelty that willingly allows people to die for lack of insurance and a sufficiently fat wallet.

That is the cruel mindset in which the contemporrary Republican Party dwells.

Yes, Democrats had better start openly embracing non-selfishness and non-cruelty. But will such a stance "sell" in a political marketplace that calls for "tough" leaders, like Romney?

The change in life expectancy from 1990 to now has been primarily due to the widespread introduction of sanitary plumbing (85%) and the use of vaccines, antibiotics and  improvement in medical practice (15%).  The positive impact of government has been large in all these areas, but only a small portion of this went to insurance programs.  A more valid comparison would be the quality of life of those over 60 for the period before Medicare existed to now.  I believe it has improved enormously over this period, which is perhaps one of the strongest arguments for universal health care, funded by the government.
In Eugene, OR - not CO!
Wrongly typed CO instead of OR.

I'm sorely disappointed in this article and wish you had done full research before proclaiming what's best for these students. As you can see by many of the impassioned comments, there are no easy answers for parents of gifted (or students). Here's my take from some time ago, "How Grade Skipping Changed Everything." http://www.ingeniosus.net/archives/how-grade-skipping-changed-everything. You'll see many considerations you overlooked. To assume that parents of gifted students and/or administrators/educators don't care about the social aspects of gifted children is a harsh generalization indeed.

You failed to mention the Iowa Acceleration Scale, one of the most widely used tools to determine academic and social readiness for gifted students considering acceleration.

I'm sad that your post will only continue to promulgate the myths that make it difficult for parents of gifted students to advocate on behalf of their sons and daughters (already a difficult endeavor). My hope is that informed readers will digest the comments, do their own research, seek out professional support, and come to their own conclusions.

I'm indebted and thankful for the many administrators and educators (including those in middle school) who take the time to truly research and learn about this population.

I hope you'll be open to the comments and rethink your stance.

Liberals often talk about health care in terms of those who do not currently have health care insurance. I think it is both more accurate and smarter politically to talk about the danger of repealing health care reform to those who currently have coverage. Everybody's health and life is at risk if health care reform is repealed. For young adults currently getting coverage under their parents plan, to people with family members who will reach the lifetime cap, for anyone that wants to switch jobs or loses theirs or who gets sick, all of them could lose access to life sustaining care.  And if you are lucky enough to keep your insurance, what good is it if you have to watch relatives and friends plead for monetary assistance to keep them alive. Or if the ability of scientists to test drugs and new procedures is hampered by lack of participants, you may be the unwitting victim of a destroyed health care system.  Or if outbreaks of diseases are harder to control due to lack of access of millions to care. We are all in this together. It is not a matter of charity or of us versus them, your life and the life of your family depends on our society's ability to protect itself. Health care reform is a major step toward protecting all of our lives. To repeal it is about the most self destructive action our society can take. Stop talking about reform in terms of helping other people, those millions without care now. Talk about how we can save all of our lives.

It is difficult to offer any solutions because the Republicans have blocked every attempt. The Republican solution to "saving" Medicare and Medicaid is to make them smaller and less accessible, because, when you buy less, of course it would cost less. Whether or not less will be adequate is quite irrelevant to them.

If a child starts early, and happily races through the three year curriculum in two years, are they allowed into the next room?  And if so, what happens when they have consumed all the curriculum available to the sixth grade, but there is no Montessori program beyond that grade?

It was later enacted in a nearly identical form by Massachesetts and called Romneycare, after the governor who signed it into law.  Now both he and every last man jack Republican are dead set against it merely because Obama was the man to bring it to the whole country. Just saw the aarp endorsement commercial today. Will repubs now show them the same disdain that they show anyone who has supported or agreed with this admin? we saw recently how pbs was put into the "hate em" column. (Again)

Enough is enough. We have to start somewhere and the aca is it when it comes to healthcare.

Darryl Issa was on Bill Maher's program this week and asked, "would it be so terrible if the American people elected a President who did what they wanted?" The answer is yes. We elect a leader to lead, not to follow. We elect a leader who can surmise a situation from the perspective of a leader and we expect him to make a sound judgment. When you change a health care system people are suspect. They feel change will hurt them. That is not the case with the Affordable Care Act. It benefits everyone. Barack Obama pushed through this bill as an advocate for the American people. Destroying it by electing a candidate who believes in nothing but the Republican tax fairy would be the worst possible choice for the country to make.

I lived in a country with universal health care.  The difference is amazing. Not having and employer choosing from a range of very bad options for their employees? Not having to worry about leaving an employer to start one's own business?  Having and accident, calling the ambulance and not worrying that there would be a ridiculous bill to pay?  Going to a doctor for well baby check-ups that included ideas like have some lemon juice to fight your cold...no pharma prescriptions pushed. Spanish healthcare was not perfect, but having catastrophic illnesses and basic wellness covered is a no brainer for business and the citizenry.  Cadillac heath care existed as  well, and was cheaper because everyone else was covered.   I had my children in a private clinic and the cost was about $1000....COvering 100% of the population is the key to having a healthy nation, healthy businesses and saving lives not competition.

You make a good point about the co-pays and deductibles that make using even their insurance policy an unaffordable proposition for many people.  The Republican approach to make things even worse?  Charge income tax on employer-sponsored health insurance.  It's what John McCain actually had the courage to admit he wanted to do.  Romney will do the same thing if elected (in order to accomodate the huge tax breaks for the rich that he is now lying about right to Obama's face), only he is such a craven coward that he will not admit it.  OBTW, he'll also eliminate the mortgage interest and state property/income tax deductions, only he won't say it because then you wouldn't vote for him, ya big meanie.

Case in point. I had a young patient (30's) who was uninsured, but was starting a new job, so waited when he found a lump on his leg. The lump grew, but he could not afford to go to the MD, he had no insurance at the time. So he waited, got the job and then waited for his insurance to kick in and finally had the lump checked. It was cancer. It had spread. We (hospice) were called in for pain management, not yet hospice. But his prognosis was grim. Plus, even with the insurance, he will have thousands in bills because of the high deductible.

It is not only the uninsured that die; the under-insured will die as well. High co-pays, huge deductibles, denied claims. All astonishing. I could tell you so many stories of patients that waited out symptoms because they were too afraid of going into debt. And these people had insurance! Imagine having none. Of course they will die. Romney's claim that the ER will take care of them is not a good answer. Of course if someone presents to the ER in full code they will work on them, insurance or not. But what if you have blood in your urine? The ER cannot work that up; you need to see a urologist or an oncologist. And if it is bladder cancer, and you have no insurance, then what? And on and on it goes.

Our system is broken. Do I think ObamaCare will solve it? No. But it will surely help. And Romney knows it. I worked in MA under RomneyCare. It did help. But people still died. Too many. It was awful to watch.

This is so typical of a foolish socialist like Krugman.  He can’t or won’t understand the benefits of the free market in providing the best outcome at the lowest price for people with a little personal initiative.  With a voucher system in an unregulated private insurance market and private health care services market to replace the big government Medicare handout, I will become a self-taught expert in all of the complexities of private medical insurance contract law and be able to either select or negotiate an outstanding agreement with the private health insurers that will pay for all the health services I could ever possibly need without any risk of being denied coverage.  Then, when the situation arises in which I actually need some significant level of medical service for a serious condition, I will quickly develop the expertise needed to fully evaluate the accuracy of a doctor’s diagnosis (after all it’s just about being able to correctly interpret various medical test results, e.g. medical imaging, blood tests, and other physiological test results) and then negotiate the best price offered by various doctors for the minimum amount of medical services needed to most effectively treat my serious condition.  With a little personal effort, how could this be more difficult than selecting the tastiest tomato to buy at the grocery store?  Krugman really needs to spend some time understanding how and why unregulated free markets always provide the very best results.

Everything else is just dross. Campaign ploys to keep the country so divided with the hopes that the small majority bring him the Oval Office.

Easy - give everyone health insurance so people stop either 1) going to ERs and running up huge bills for simple problems or 2) ending up with prolonged, expensive hospitalizations because they could not see a primary care doctor. Universal health insurance would save us money. More money can be found by declaring fewer people disabled - many of the disabled simply go on federal disability because it is the only way for them to get health insurance to treat the health problem that made them disabled in the first place.
